clean_content:
Definition / general

* According to WHO 2005, ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor with features of [calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html) or dentinogenic ghost cell tumor* Classified as an odontogenic carcinoma, which includes:
    + [Metastasizing (malignant) ameloblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillamalignantameloblastoma.html)+ [Ameloblastic carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaameloblasticcarcinoma.html)+ [Primary intraosseous squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaprimaryintraosseouscarcinoma.html)
          - Solid type- Derived from keratocystic odontogenic tumor- Derived from odontogenic cysts+ [Clear cell odontogenic carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaclearcellodontogenic.html)+ Ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma

Terminology

* Odontogenic ghost cell tumor* Calcifying ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma* Malignant epithelial odontogenic ghost cell tumor* Aggressive epithelial ghost cell odontogenic tumor* Carcinoma arising in a calcifying odontogenic cyst* Malignant calcifying ghost cell odontogenic tumor* Malignant calcifying odontogenic cyst

Epidemiology

* Rare, < 40 cases reported in literature and more than half from Asia* More common in males

Sites

* Maxilla more common than mandible

Etiology

* Malignancy thought to arise from calcifying ondontogenic cysts (COCs) with features of either calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor or dentinogenic ghost cell tumor

Clinical features

* Can present as painful, hard swelling in the maxilla or mandible* Can also have paresthesia associated with root resorption or tooth displacement

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis dependent on clinical, radiologic and pathologic correlation

Radiology description

* Most commonly seen as a mixed radiolucency and radio opacity with ill defined margins

Prognostic factors

* Overall 5 year survival rate is 73% and recurrence is common

Case reports

* 21 year old man with ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma (GCOC) ([Pan Afr Med J 2015;21:260](26523195))* 54 year old man with tender swelling in the malar region ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2015;19:371](26980967))* 64 year old woman with metastatic odontogenic carcinoma arising from dentinogenic ghost cell tumor ([Rare Tumors 2015;7:5813](26500725))* 70 year old woman with rapid onset of painful swelling right maxillary tumor ([J Clin Exp Dent 2014;6:e602](25674335))

Treatment

* Composite surgical excision, may be followed by radiation

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  
  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4607801/figure/F0001/)

Diffused swelling on the left side of face obliterating the nasolabial fold

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih02.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4312695/figure/F1)

Clinical and MRI examination

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih03.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4607801/figure/F0002/)

Axial section CT scan

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Ameloblastomatous areas: peripheral palisading, reverse polarization, stellate reticulum* Ghost cells (polygonal epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm that have lost their nuclei but maintain a faint outline of cellular and nuclear membrane)
    + Ghost cells may be calcified* Atypia with changes such as increased cellularity, pleomorphism, mitosis, necrosis and infiltrative growth

Microscopic (histologic) images

Images hosted on other servers:  
  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih04.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4774292/figure/F1/)

Ameloblastoma-like areas

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih05.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4774292/figure/F2/)

Ghost cells

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih06.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4774292/figure/F5/)

Cytologic atypia with increased mitotic rate

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih07.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4600987/figure/fig001/)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih08.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4607801/figure/F0005/)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicghost_nih09.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4607801/figure/F0006/)

Ghost cells

Immunohistochemistry & special stains

* Positive for [pan-cytokeratin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html), [p63](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp63.html)* Often have an increased [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html) proliferative index* Can also show [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html) expression

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* Limited literature, but aberrations of Wnt signaling pathway with beta catenin overexpression have been shown in calcifying cystic odontogenic tumors ([APMIS 2008;116:206](18377586))

Differential diagnosis

* [Ameloblastic carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaameloblasticcarcinoma.html)
  + Variable features of ameloblastoma: peripheral palisading, reverse polarization, stellate reticulum-like cells+ Features of malignancy include cytological atypia, high N:C ratio, increased mitoses with atypical forms, necrosis+ Can also metastasize+ No ghost cells* **Benign epithelial odontogenic neoplasm**
    + Occurs in posterior mandible, intraosseous location+ Variably sized polyhedral eosinophilic epithelial cells with distinct cell borders are arranged in small clusters, trabeculae, islands or a sheet-like pattern+ Nuclear pleomorphism is expected, but without appreciable mitotic activity+ Eosinophilic amyloid-like matrix material is haphazardly deposited in association with the tumor islands, and calcified concentric profiles (Liesegang rings) are often identified* [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (CCOT)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html)
      + Benign cystic tumor of odontogenic origin, aka “Gorlin cyst” or “Calcifying odontogenic cyst”+ Can have “ameloblastic” features: columnar or cuboidal basal cells with lumen lined by tissue resembling stellate reticulum+ Will have ghost cells or anucleate epithelial cells+ Should not have cytologic atypia, increased mitotic activity, necrosis* [Calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor (CEOT)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingepithelial.html)
